tn.text: Moses continues reminding the people of Israel of what happened in the past.
These are names of kings. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:03|1:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of cities. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:03|1:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Yahweh said to me, 'Do not fear him; ... given you ... under your control ... You will do ... as you did ... at Heshbon.'
tn.text: Yahweh is speaking to Moses as if Moses were the Israelites, so the command "do not fear" and all instances of "you" and "your" are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: fear him ... over him ... his people and his land
tn.text: Here the words "him" and "his" refer to Og.
Yahweh speaks of what he will do as if he had already done it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])

tn.ref: You will do to him as you did to Sihon
tn.text: The word "him" is a metonym for "his people." AT: "You will destroy Og and his people as you did Sihon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: and all his people were put under our control
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "and Yahweh put all of Og's people under our control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: not one of his people remained
tn.text: This is a litotes that is used to emphasize that the Israelites did not let anyone live. AT: "all of his people were dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: there was not one city that we did not take
tn.text: This is a double negative that emphasizes that they took all of the 60 cities. AT: "we took every one of the cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"60 cities" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is the name of a region within Bashan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel of what happened in the past.

tn.ref: These were all cities fortified with
tn.text: "These were all cities protected by"
"in addition to" or "not including"
This is the name of a king. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:03|1:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a city. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:03|1:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"killing all the people who lived in every city"
Moses continues to speak to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: out of the hand of the two kings
tn.text: Here the metonym "out of the hand of" means "from the control of." AT: "from the control of the two kings" or "from the two kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Amorite people ... land of Bashan ... town of Edrei ... King Og" Translate these as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:03|1:4]].

This refers to the land across the Jordan River, to the east of Israel. Moses was east of the Jordan when he said this. AT: "east of the Jordan River" Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:01|1:1]].
Translate these words as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:24|2:24]].
These are all names of the same mountain which is at the northern border of Bashan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is high, flat land between the Arnon River and Mount Gilead.
This is the name of a city near Edrei. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Moses continues to speak to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: For of the remnant ... the way people measure
tn.text: This is background information about King Og. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:10|2:11]].
"Pay attention to the important thing I am going to tell you."

tn.ref: Was it not in Rabbah, ... live?
tn.text: The writer uses a question to remind the people of Israel that they could go to Rabbah and see how large Og must have been. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. Possible meanings are 1) "It was in Rabbah, ... live." or 2) "It is in Rabbah ... live." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
A cubit is 46 centimeters. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]])
"according to the cubit most people use"
Moses continues reminding the people of what happened in the past.
Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:36|2:36]].
Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:24|2:24]].
Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:03:03|3:4]].

tn.ref: The same territory is called the land of Rephaim
tn.text: The writer begins to present background information about the land that the people of Israel captured. If your language has a way of showing that what follows is background information, you should use it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:10|2:11]].
This continues the background information about the land the people of Israel captured. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:deu:03:12|3:13]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are people groups who lived west of Bashan. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Translators may make a footnote that says: "The name 'Havvoth Jair' means 'tent villages of Jair' or 'realm of Jair.'"
Moses continues to speak to the people of Israel.
Here "I" refers to Moses.

Machir was the son of Manasseh. He had died before Moses gave this land. The name is a metonym for the descendants of the person. AT: "to the descendants of Machir." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This is the name of the valley of the Arnon River. It creates the border between Moab and the Amorites. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:24|2:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

This is the name of a river that created the border between Sihon's land and the land of the Ammonites. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:02:36|2:37]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Moses continues to speak to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: Another of its borders is also
tn.text: "The western border of the Reubenite and Gadite territory is"
"the Sea of Chinnereth." This is the same place as "the Sea of Galilee" or "the Lake of Gennesaret." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a mountain in the northern part of the Abarim mountain range. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Moses continues to speak to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: I commanded you at that time
tn.text: Moses reminds the tribe of Reuben, the tribe of Gad, and the half tribe of Manasseh that they must help the other Israelites conquer the rest of the land God promised them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"will take your weapons and cross the Jordan River ahead of"

tn.ref: your brothers, the people of Israel
tn.text: "your fellow Israelites"
Moses continues speaking to the tribes of Reuben and Gad and half of the tribe of Manasseh.

tn.ref: Yahweh gives rest to your brothers
tn.text: The writer speaks as if the ability to rest were a physical object that could be given as a gift. The word "rest" is also a metaphor for peaceful life in which there is no war. AT: "Yahweh allows your brothers to rest" or "Yahweh allows your brothers to stop fighting wars and live peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This refers to the land across the Jordan River, to the east of Israel. Moses was east of the Jordan when he said this. AT: "east of the Jordan River." Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:01|1:1]].
Moses is emphasizing that the other tribes must possess their land before Yahweh will permit these three tribes to possess their land. "only then are you to return."
Moses continues reminding the people of Israel about what happened in the past.
Here "eyes" refers to Joshua. AT: "You have seen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Moses continues reminding the people about what happened in the past.
Here "I" refers to Moses. This means he asked God in a very earnest, emotional way.
Here "your servant" is a polite way of speaking to someone with greater authority. AT: "to show me, your servant,"
Here the metonym "hand" means control or power. AT: "your power" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: for what god is there ... acts?
tn.text: Moses uses a question to emphasize that Yahweh is the only God with the power to do the works he has done. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "for there is no god ... acts." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These two extremes together mean "anywhere." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
"west of the Jordan River." When Moses spoke these words to Yahweh, he was east of the Jordan River in Moab.
Moses continues telling the people of Israel what happened in the past.

tn.ref: Yahweh was angry with me because of you
tn.text: This refers to when Moses disobeyed what Yahweh told him to do because Moses was angry with the people of Israel. Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:01:37|1:37]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Translate this as it is in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:03:17|3:17]].
The words "lift up your eyes" are an idiom that means look. AT: "look"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh continues speaking to Moses.
This is the name of a town in Moab near Mount Pisgah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
